{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-10048].
  {panel}

A page content that has the following markup (with special characters):
{noformat}
test ÁRVÍZTŰRŐ

_test ÁRVÍZTŰRŐ_ 

*test ÁRVÍZTŰRŐ* 
{noformat}

Following the steps suggested in the following documentation resolve the character problems when exported to PDF format (installed the verdana.ttf):
* http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/DOC/Create+PDF+in+another+language

However, the bold and italic fonts does not take effect (see screenshot: result1.pdf). Installing the {{Verdana Bold}} instead later, would change all the fonts in *bold* form when coverting to PDF instead (see screenshot: result2.pdf). 
It appears that the {{fop.xml}} only takes up one font at a time even if there are multiple fonts format(see screenshot: result3.jpg) being installed:
{noformat}
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>

<fop>
  <renderers>
    <renderer mime="application/pdf">
      <fonts>
        <font metrics-url="file:/${confluence.home}/fonts/verdanab-metrics.xml" embed-url="file:/${confluence.home}/fonts/verdanab.ttf" kerning="yes">
          <font-triplet name="verdanab" style="normal" weight="normal"/>
          <font-triplet name="verdanab" style="normal" weight="bold"/>
          <font-triplet name="verdanab" style="italic" weight="normal"/>
          <font-triplet name="verdanab" style="italic" weight="bold"/>
        </font>
      </fonts>
    </renderer>
  </renderers>
</fop>
{noformat}
fields.summary: Only a single style of custom font is supported for PDF export

{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-10030].
  {panel}

Most of the queries against CONTENT table use 'lower' db function for a title field. The goes for (space) key field in SPACES table. 
We do it to make a case insensitive comparison, however it means that db2 does not use the existing indexes for those fields and performs a full table scan.
This results in a poor performance. 

This can be applicable to other database too, but it is not verified. Also other databases may have global 'case sensitivity' flag.
fields.summary: db2: queries that use 'lower' do not use index because of case sensitivity

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-9965].
  {panel}

I'm still a relatively new Confluence user, but there are a couple of things that I've noticed:
* The most popular issue in the CONF project has 143 votes
* The top 50 issues in the CONF project have an average of ~53 votes each

According to the Sales Team's e-mail signature (incidentally the site shows different values), there are over 7000 Confluence users in over 75 countries - e.g. _the most important issue only has the vote of ~2% of the total number of Confluence instances_. I don't think it is necessarily reasonable to assume that the views of 2% are truly representative of the majority - especially since there appears to be a far greater proportion of technical users than any other type of user logging/commenting on issues.

This is concerning to me considering Atlassian use these votes to determine the order in which issues/feature requests are addressed - e.g. *major product decisions are being made based on very little data*. A good analogy would be a movie studio - they wouldn't decide to make a sequel after reading a couple of critics' reviews, they poll millions of peoples' opinions by counting ticket sales. I definitely think effort needs to be made to increase the number of votes on Confluence issues.


What I'm proposing is basically a means to:
* Vastly increase visibility of (and by proxy, voters on) Confluence-related issues
* Reduce the number of duplicate/similar issues being logged - e.g. Atlassian staff can spend less time managing the tracking system and more time working on the issues
* Reduce barriers to browsing/watching/voting so that the views of a far greater variety of users are also represented
* Make it easy for users to stay up-to-date with new issues
* Make it easier for Atlassian staff to prioritise issues effectively, since the differences in votes between issues would probably be greatly exaggerated rather than 1-10 votes

Essentially what I'd like to see is a sort of 'Dashboard' added to the Global Administration Console - preferably on the 99% empty _console.action_ page. This 'Dashboard' would basically be a hybrid between Confluence's main Dashboard & the Plugin Repository, and display things like:
* The 10-20 most recently logged issues
* The 10-20 most recently updated issues
* Watched issues
* Voted issues

Similar to the plugin repository, each item should have drill-down capabilities to see a cut-down version of the corresponding JIRA issues page (e.g. details/comments/status with simple actions such as vote/watch).

To prevent multiple people from a single site/instance voting on issues, a JIRA account could automatically be created based on the Server ID (or other uniquely identifying data) - e.g. each admin would share a common view.

This is just a starting point - I'd be keen/happy to be involved with the planning of this feature from a design/functionality perspective (don't ask me to code anything though :) ).

When copying and pasting double hyphens from Microsoft Word into the Rich Text editor, Confluence always converts them into strike-through text rather than em-dashes or en-dashes.

For example, if you type this in Word:
This text\-\-if you can imagine\-\-is an example of em-dashes.
Then Word converts the double-hyphens into em-dashes (because the user did not put spaces on either side of the hyphens).

But, if you copy the text from Word into Confluence, then Confluence automatically converts the text into strike-through text:
This text -if you can imagine- is an example of em-dashes.

Please interpret double-hyphens first, before looking for strike-through text. In this way, parenthetical statements copied from Word will be shown with en-dashes rather than strike-through text.

In very large organization, some labels are used for special meanings. For example:
'article-for-review'
'delete-me'
'featured-article'
'specification-document'
'approved'
'obsolete'

While every effort is made to make things wide open, and deal with 'mistakes' through 'education' rather than control, in many cases the COST in time and resources to educate people on the proper use of high-impact labels outweighs the benefit.  While most labels can and should remain open, significant efficiencies and time savings can be achieved by limiting the use of certain labels to certain groups. For example:

If the 'delete-me' label above was linked to an automated review and deletion process, it could be limited to only be used by people in the 'moderators' group. Anyone could use a 'review-for-deletion' label, but not the specific 'delete-me' label.

Likewise, if the 'approved' label was restricted to the people that have the approval authority for a given process or expenditure, then a separate approval process would not be needed outside of confluence: the approved label could be used with certainty.

Further, if labels like 'featured-article' was linked to articles that were shown on the top-level page of a large organization, and 'specification-document' label was used as a 'document class' with a special meaning that only a fraction of the organization really understood, and the use of these were limited to a group called "Users-that-have-completed-confluence-training" or "users-in-the-specification-group", then education on certain high-impact topics could be achieved proactively rather than retroactively.
fields.summary: Create a permission system to restrict add or remove label actions for individual labels

Update Confluence SOAP API to be at least as current as XML-RPC API, add more service methods for General Admin, Space Admin, Page/Content Admin, User/Group Admin, and implement processes/policies to keep it up to speed as Confluence develops.

There are so many more things that people could be doing with Confluence if the Remote APIs were bulked up.

And doesn't have to be that hard for people to keep up-to-date with the API as it changes. Anyone using Maven 2 in any project could use the org.codehaus.mojo axistools-maven-plugin to very easily and automatically generate SOAP client code by just including the following plugin in their project and putting wsdl into a wsdl directory:

            <!-- target = axistools:wsdl2java -->
            <plugin>
                <groupId>org.codehaus.mojo</groupId>
                <artifactId>axistools-maven-plugin</artifactId>
                <configuration>
                    <sourceDirectory>wsdl</sourceDirectory>
                    <packageSpace>csum.confluence.permissionmgmt.soap</packageSpace>
                    <testCases>false</testCases>
                    <serverSide>false</serverSide>
                    <subPackageByFileName>true</subPackageByFileName>
                </configuration>
                <executions>
                    <execution>
                        <goals>
                            <goal>wsdl2java</goal>
                        </goals>
                    </execution>
                </executions>
            </plugin>

It would be great if there was a "Dynamic User Group" plugin component type. While I'm sure this sort of thing could be done with Crowd, many clients are using other SSO and LDAP systems which are difficult to cater for from within Confluence.

The plugin component would be used to create "fake" user groups within Confluence. To the rest of Confluence, they would appear like normal local groups, you could even add users to them (although it would be up to the plugin to decide what to do in this case).

Some examples:

1. Intersection Groups

The plugin config would allow an admin to define any number of intersection groups - each intersection group would list users that appear in two or more specific groups.

For example, let's say I have groups for job roles and countries. An intersection group could be made to collate all users who are both in Sweeden and are also Principle Engineers.

2. Privilege Groups

You could create a group that would list all space administrators.

3. Top Contributors Group

A group to list 50 of the most prolific contributors in Confluence.

4. Email Groups

A group to collate all people with a specific domain in their email address. This is really useful in cases where Confluence is used as an extranet as it would make collating everyone from company X in to a group simply by their email address.

In terms of social networking, etc., the Dynamic User Group component would be extremely useful.

EDIT: The dynamic groups would ideally have a flag to distinguish them from normal groups (in case any plugins or other functionality needs to know the difference).

Currently, Confluence does not provide a group-specific warning that an  Administrator is removing a Group that is being used to restrict pages. (It only provides general cautionary language).  There is also no easy way of finding out what if any pages the Group has been used to restrict access to.  Also, the Confluence Search feature does not include permission restrictions within its scope so it does not locate the pages.  

This is very serious since inadvertently removing a Group completely removes the access restriction function it was providing to any pages (and children pages) it was specified on - potentially opening up the page's and children pages' contents to the entire user community (if there are no other restrictions).

This request is to provide three features:
1. When an administrator attempts to remove a Group, if the Group is being used to restrict any pages they would get a warning message along with a complete list of those restricted pages, (ordered by Space).  
2. The Manage Groups page should include a button next to each Group so the Administrator can easily get the above list of pages that have that Group specified as a restriction without having to hit the Remove button (e.g. a button called something like "Restrictions (?)" or "Test Usage (?)" next to the current Remove button). 
3. The Confluence Search feature should include Groups specified within restrictions within its scope - so specifying a group as the search criteria locates the pages its has been specified on.

Thank you.
fields.summary: Removing a group should warn about page restrictions which include that group

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-9474].
  {panel}

The space export to PDF makes nice use of the PDF Bookmarks feature. Each page from teh selected confluence pages gets a bookmark tag, which gives us a nice "Index" or TOC on the left bar when one opens the document in PDF reader.

*However*, the PDF export of a page feature fails to make use of this very cool and useful feature. Which forces us to use the TOC macro. However, that TOC is not as good because it does not "float" like the bookmarks do.

*Suggestion*: make the page PDF export also bookmark the content. It can be done by automatically giving a bookmark to each Level 1 heading.
*would be cool if one could control if this is done to Level 1, 2, 3....
fields.summary: PDF export: use Bookmarks feature
